results.title: Don't Be Scalped
results.creator_credit: New South Wales. Dept. of Labour and Industry, Fortune Film Productions and R.D. Hansen
results.brief_description:
In this 1960 film, we see female machine operators working in factories. The film focuses on a woman named Judy, describing her outfit and the dangers associated with wearing high-heeled shoes, full skirts, jewellery and long hair while operating a machine. The film then shows Judy dressed in the correct clothing options, including protective shoes, coveralls and cap to cover her hair. It also gives advice on how to lift heavy objects. As opposed to the safety films directed at male workers, the narrator focuses on physical appearance throughout the film, describing Judy as attractive, charming and pretty, and warning against fatigue, wear on clothing, disfigurement and scalping.

Produced by Fortune Film Productions and the New South Wales Department of Labour and Industry.

There are several jumps in the soundtrack throughout the film due to missing frames.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Think twice
results.creator_credit: Waterside Workers' Federation of Australia. Film Unit., James Levy, Keith Gow and Norma Disher
results.brief_description:
This 1958 film demonstrates the hazards associated with the boilermaking trade. It outlines the dangers of heat, infrared and ultraviolet rays and fumes, which are encountered with oxyacetylene and electric arc welding. It shows how accidents happen with each of these dangers and the types of injury suffered, including burns, eye injury and blindness, and serious illness caused by inhalation of fumes. It also shows how accidental explosions can occur when using welding equipment, and the importance of safe practices when welding, particularly in confined spaces.

The film emphasises the protective gear and equipment recommended at the time that should be used in order to avoid these hazards. It also shows teenage apprentices, some very young, being trained in safety practices. The film takes place at Cockatoo Docks and Engineering Company, a shipbuilding company that operated on Cockatoo Island, Sydney, between 1933 and 1992.

Produced by the Waterside Workers’ Federation of Australia Film Unit and presented by the Boilermakers’ Society of Australia and Protector Safety Products Pty. Ltd. Sydney, Australia.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: [Remix: Sunnies]
results.brief_description:
Worn at the beach or on a bush walk, or simply as a style statement, this playful short film is a tribute to the fashion accessory, and sun-smart, sun glasses. Set to a boss nova soundtrack, this short work is a tribute to ‘shades’, showing people wearing sun glasses cut from home movies and short works in the ACMI Collection. Featured are some of fashion’s best styles of eye wear from the 1940s to the 1970s.

ACMI gratefully acknowledge the following donors and creators in the compilation of this work: Tasmanian Archive and Heritage Office; Elenor Peach; Barry Parsons; The Gadsden Family and Neville Daley.

results.title: Waterfront safety
results.creator_credit: Western Australian Government Film Unit and Western Australia. Dept. of Labour
results.brief_description:
This 1966 film takes place on the wharfs and ships at Fremantle Harbour, demonstrating safe working methods for waterside workers. It shows the correct handling of various types of cargo, including logs, grain and phosphate mined from Nauru. It emphasises the use of protective clothing and equipment. The film also shows the prevention and control of fires, including fire fighting ships.

Produced by the Western Australian Government Film Unit and presented by the Western Australian Department of Labour with Accident Prevention Organisation (Shipping).

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Rabbit Control [Part 1: Poisoning with 1080]
results.creator_credit: Conservation Forests and Lands, John Atkins and Ian Blythman
results.brief_description: This program narrated by Maurie Fields shows the problem of pest control in rural Victoria, and the adverse effects on farming if rabbit populations are not controlled. Part 1 explains the proper steps and procedure in using the poison 1080, the various safety precautions, equipment and supplies and tidy up details.

results.title: This woman is not a car
results.creator_credit: Arid Zone Productions, Jenny Jacobs, Vyner Gillespie and Margaret Dodd
results.brief_description: A mother, isolated in an outer Adelaide suburb, drives a station wagon full of children to a distant beach. Imagination and reality fuse. Her sense of herself is assaulted by car fetishists in a rural service station. Memory, fear and fantasy are interwoven as this experimental film takes woman’s assigned role in the ‘Australian Dream’ to its absurd conclusion. Music: Brian Eno, The Fabulous Nudes, The Pelaco Bros. Actors include Pauline Sedgwick, Daniel Sedgwick, Lisa Sedgwick, Gareth Sedgwick and Katrina Sedgwick.

results.title: Kanga Cricket
results.brief_description: An Australian Cricket Board primary development programme for kids, sponsored by the Australian Diary Corporation and supported by the Commonwealth Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism. Demonstrates the concept of Kanga cricket, a simplified adaptation of traditional cricket rules introduced into Australian schools. Former Australian cricket captain Kim Hughes and Peter Russell-Clarke participate.

results.title: Plastic economy: banking and technology
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development and Tony Paice
results.brief_description: Shows the effects of technology on the banking industry and the future prospects for the industry and employees. Incorporates union, industry and business views.

results.title: Skyhooks: the video collection
results.creator_credit: Musical Films, Ray Argall and Christina Pozzan
results.brief_description: Traces the history of Melbourne pop group ‘Skyhooks’ using video clips, concert footage, backstage interviews and segments from Australian television in the 70’s and 80’s. Formed in 1973, Skyhooks quickly acquired popularity amongst youths, while simultaneously arousing controversy in conservative Australia. This compilation tape presents 19 of their songs drawn from concerts, and video clips interspersed with television appearances, newspaper clippings and interviews.

results.title: The Destruction of St. Patrick's College 1971
results.brief_description: The old St Patrick’s College was demolished to make way for an ecclesiastic office building. Professor Hartley Gratten, of the University of Texas considers, against the background of the demolition by Whelan the Wrecker, why Australians ignore their national heritage.
